item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
David see here: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.sqlserver.management.common.aspx

The Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Common namespace resides in the Microsoft.SqlServer.ConnectionInfo.dll assembly file.

By using the Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Common namespace, you can do the following:

Connect to an instance of SQL Server.

Control the connection settings.

Run Transact-SQL statements directly.

Capture the Transact-SQL statements that are generated by the SMO program.

Manage transactions.

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.content:encoded:
Very Nice Denis. Here is VB.NET for SSIS 2005

The parser would not allow the brackets in the code for the pattern on regex replace so anyone that uses this be sure to add the brackets in

Imports System
Imports System.Collections.Generic
Imports System.Text.RegularExpressions
Imports System.Data
Imports System.Data.SqlClient
Imports System.Math
Imports System.IO
Imports System.Collections.Specialized
Imports Microsoft.SqlServer.Dts.Runtime
Imports Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo
Imports Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Smo.Agent

Public Class ScriptMain

Public Sub Main()
Dim sc As New StringCollection
Dim so As New ScriptingOptions
Dim tw As TextWriter
Dim srv As New Server(“LKFSQLTST01”)
srv.ConnectionContext.LoginSecure = True

so.IncludeDatabaseContext = True
Dim script As String = “”
Dim JobName As String = “”
Dim filename As String = “”

For Each J As Job In srv.JobServer.Jobs
JobName = J.Name.ToString()
sc = J.Script(so)
For Each s As String In sc
script += s
Next

filename = “C:” + JobName + “.sql”
filename = Regex.Replace(filename, “[/:?’=|]”, “”)

tw = New StreamWriter(filename)
tw.Write(script)
tw.Close()

script = “”

Next

Dts.TaskResult = Dts.Results.Success
End Sub

End Class
